articles.title: About
articles.contents:
Data graphics
I started doing data visualization work with a research group in engineering education around 2008. The iterative process we developed to “find the story” in our data has been instrumental in shaping my approach to data graphics. You can read more about our research at https://midfield.online/.
I occasionally write about visual rhetoric, graph design, and R on my Data Stories blog.

Music
My dad was a guitar player and taught me my first chords. I’ve been songwriting, performing, and composing since my teens. I’ve posted some draft tracks to SoundCloud.
A favorite musical pilgrimage is the annual Swannanoa Gathering near Asheville, NC in late July.

Work life
I am a graduate of California State University, Northridge (1991), and the University of Washington (1993, 1995), all in mechanical engineering. I taught at Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology from 2000–2020. My favorite courses were design, system dynamics, measurement systems, and data visualization. I retired from teaching in 2020.

articles.title: Data stories workshop
articles.description: Visualizing quantitative data: what makes a chart effective?
articles.contents:
Welcome
In this workshop, we introduce a few basic ideas on creating effective charts of quantitative data.
For most of us, our education entailed years of training and practice using the tools of effective written and spoken communication, what we might term verbal rhetoric. Yet very few of us experience anywhere near as thorough a grounding in the tools of effective graphical communication, or visual rhetoric.
This helps explain why folks who may be perfectly competent otherwise can uncritically produce ghastly charts such as the “solar output profile” chart below.
Figure 1: Example of an ineffective chart. Even if you take the time to understand what the chart purports to show, there is no compelling message for the audience to take away. Source: Clarke et al. (2021)By the end of the workshop you should be able to
Describe limitations of common graph types
Describe a graph type you had not encountered before
Explain how you might begin to think critically about visual information

articles.title: Session 1
articles.description:
Limitations of common graph types. Demonstrating how to avoid   
limitations and improve perception, reasoning, and credibility.
articles.contents:
Limitations of common graph types
In the first session we demonstrate the perceptual limitations of common graph types and suggest more effective alternatives.

The rationale behind alternative designs is illustrated with the goals of
Improving perception of stories in the data
Making it easier to reason quantitatively about the data
Enhancing our credibility with the audience
Materials
worksheets I suggest you have a printed copy of these worksheets to write in during the workshop. We have a number of think-write-share activities that for many people work best in writing.
slides used during the workshop.

articles.title: Session 2
articles.description:
Expanding your graphical repertoire. Illustrating a repertoire of 
graph types and how they are suited to specific data structures.
articles.contents:
Expanding your graphical repertoire
In the second session we illustrate a repertoire of graph types and
how they are suited to specific data structures and answering specific
types of questions.

The session should encourage you to:
Understand the structure of your data
Understand the type of question the data can answer
Explore different graph types suited to the data and the
question
Keep reading and learning—an unfamiliar design may be just what you
need

articles.title: Session 3
articles.description:
Critical thinking about visual information—a case study. 
Detecting and correcting deliberate visual lies that attempt 
to restrict reproductive rights.
articles.contents:
Critical thinking about visual information—a case
study
In the third session we study the visual rhetoric of a deliberate
visual lie in the pursuit of restricting reproductive rights. We focus
on
How the authors abuse the conventions of visual rhetoric to serve
their rhetorical goals
What legitimate stories these data tell
What legitimate questions the data raise
